MUSIC INTER WOVEN INTO LIFE OF BALINESE, NAEB EXPLAINS
The meaning that music and their own native orchestras have for
the people of the Island of Bali is explored in "The Fighting Cock Refrain",
a broadcast which concludes the second "Ways of Mankind" thirteen weeks’
series presented as an adult education project by the National Association of
Educational Broadcasters.
One of a subseries of three programs devoted to the Balinese and
their culture, "The Fighting Cock Refrain" will be heard at -- (time) -- on -
(date) - - (name).
Dr. Walter Goldschmidt, As eociate Professor of Anthropology and
Sociology at the University of California, supervised the entire Ways of
Mankind series. For the Balinese scripts, Colin McPhee collected and made
available recorded music from the Island of Bali. Consultants included Miss
Claire Holt and Margaret Mead of the American Museum of Natural History.
Walter Newman wrote "The Fighting Cock Refrain" and Andrew Allan
produced it.
The story of "The Fighting Cock Refrain" tells how a Balinese
musician falls into disgrace through divulging secrets to the musicians of a
rival village, but even at the height of his humiliation jubilantly plans a
musical "comeback".
Life for the Balinese peasant is lived largely within his village.
His village is governed by a council of all married men, who apply the
traditional regulations to preserve order and maintain the cooperation
necessary for irrigating and working their rice fields.
Very nearly every village, too, has its orchestra club, the pride
and focus of its social life. To the Balinese, the love of music is the love
of playing it. and night after night they will practice out of sheer pleasure,
until without notation they can create and reproduce intricate symphonic
masterpieces. "The Fighting Cock Refrain" seeks to give a true under¬
standing of the meaning that music and their orchestras have for the people
of the Island of Bali.
